'''Billy Wayne Yates''' (born March 13, 1963) is an American [[country music]] artist. He has released ten studio albums and has charted four singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts, including "[[Flowers (Billy Yates song)|Flowers]]" which reached number 36 in 1997. Yates also co-wrote [[George Jones]]' singles "[[I Don't Need Your Rockin' Chair]]" and "[[Choices (Billy Yates song)|Choices]]", which were released in 1993 and 1999 respectively. Other artists who have recorded Yates' work include [[Ricochet (band)|Ricochet]], [[Ricky Van Shelton]], and [[Kenny Chesney]]. In addition to his work as a singer and songwriter, Yates is the owner of the songwriting and publishing company Smokin' Grapes, which was founded in 2006. Yates' musical style is defined by [[neotraditional country]] and [[honky-tonk]] influences, and has been favorably compared to artists such as [[Gene Watson]].

==Biography==
===1963–1992: Early life===
Billy Wayne Yates was born on March 13, 1963, in [[Doniphan, Missouri]].<ref name="whitburn"/> He was raised on his family's farm, where he took inspiration from the various country music artists to which his family listened, such as [[Jim Reeves]] and [[Ernest Tubb]].<ref name="bull"/> His father was a [[barber]] and would often pay his son to shine customers' shoes at his barber shop.<ref name="not just">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/179672762/ | title=Billy Yates not just a songwriter | work=The Tribune | date=September 2, 1997 | accessdate=July 16, 2021 | pages=3B}}</ref> Yates and his father would also sing every Sunday on a local radio show hosted by the town's radio station, [[KDFN]].<ref name="bull">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/321608755/ | title=Billy Yates to perform at Bull Shoals theater | work=Baxter Bulletin | date=April 22, 2004 | accessdate=July 16, 2021 | pages=1B, 2B}}</ref> He did not otherwise perform publicly until he gave an impromptu performance of "[[Crying My Heart Out Over You]]" at a local show in [[Wappapello, Missouri]], as a teen.<ref name="bull"/><ref name="allmusic">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/billy-yates-mn0000095814/biography | title=Billy Yates biography | publisher=[[AllMusic]] | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref> He continued to perform at this show for three years until his father encouraged him to also get a barber's license. After doing so, Yates began working at a barber in Doniphan during the daytime while also working as a nighttime disc jockey at KDFN.<ref name="file">{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-RandR/1990s/1997/RR-1997-06-13.pdf | title=New artist fact file | journal=Radio & Records | pages=54 | date=June 13, 1997}}</ref>

===1993–1999: "I Don't Need Your Rockin' Chair" and ''Billy Yates''===
[[File:George Jones.jpg|thumb|170px|left|[[George Jones]] recorded Yates' compositions "[[I Don't Need Your Rockin' Chair]]" and "[[Choices (Billy Yates song)|Choices]]".|alt=Country music singer George Jones singing while holding a guitar.]]
Yates traveled between Missouri and [[Nashville, Tennessee]], several times in pursuit of a music career. He found brief work as a [[demo (music)|demo]] singer in 1982, but felt at the time that he was unprepared.<ref name="cst page 1">{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=897 | title=Billy Yates: what you see is what you get (page 1) | publisher=Country Standard Time | date=June 2003 | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref><ref name="cst page 2">{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/article.asp?xid=897&p=2 | title=Billy Yates: what you see is what you get (page 1) | publisher=Country Standard Time | date=June 2003 | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref> At this time, Yates supported himself financially by continuing to work as a barber.<ref name="file"/> Upon returning to Nashville in the early 1990s, he got his first songwriter publishing contract with Hori Pro Entertainment, which led to [[George Jones]] recording two of his songs for his 1992 album ''[[Walls Can Fall]]''. "[[I Don't Need Your Rockin' Chair]]", one of the two songs recorded by Jones, was released as a single that year and was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]].<ref name="allmusic"/> The success of the Jones cuts led to Yates signing with [[Curb Records]] in 1993. He released one single titled "Turn for the Worse", which was also recorded by [[Dude Mowrey]] that same year.<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Gavin-Report/90/93/Gavin-1993-09-17.pdf | title=New releases | journal=Gavin Report | pages=22 | date=September 17, 1993}}</ref> In addition, [[Kenny Chesney]] would later cover the song on his 1996 album ''[[Me and You (Kenny Chesney album)|Me and You]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/me-and-you-mw0000648028 | title=''Me and You'' | publisher=AllMusic | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref> Yates also co-wrote the title track of [[Ricky Van Shelton]]'s 1993 album ''[[A Bridge I Didn't Burn]]''.<ref name="nerve"/>

Yates left Curb after only the one single; he would later tell the blog Country Music News International that "nothing came" of its release.<ref name="cmni"/> Despite this, he continued to write songs, record demos, and perform at songwriter showcases throughout Nashville.<ref name="not just"/> Among his successes as a songwriter was "From Good to Bad to Worse to Gone", a cut from [[Ricochet (band)|Ricochet]]'s [[Ricochet (Ricochet album)|self-titled debut album]] in 1996.<ref name="nerve"/> In 1997, record producer [[Garth Fundis]] heard Yates perform at a Nashville club and chose to sign him to [[Almo Sounds]], an independent label whose Nashville division he was president of at the time.<ref name="file"/> The label released his debut album ''[[Billy Yates (album)|Billy Yates]]'' that same year;<ref name="allmusic"/> Yates co-wrote every song and co-produced with Fundis.<ref name="cst debut"/> "I Smell Smoke" was initially selected as the lead single, but due to a large number of stations playing "[[Flowers (Billy Yates song)|Flowers]]", the label began officially promoting that song as a single in May 1997.<ref name="file"/><ref>{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/hd2/IDX-Business/Music/Archive-RandR-IDX/IDX/90s/97/RR-1997-05-16-OCR-Page-0055.pdf | title=Going for Adds | journal=Radio & Records | pages=55 | date=May 16, 1997}}</ref> "Flowers" went on to reach number 36 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts in 1997.<ref name="whitburn"/> The song came about when co-writer Monty Criswell presented the idea to Yates during a songwriting session. It is about a man who expresses remorse after his wife dies in an automobile crash caused by him [[driving under the influence]]. Yates described the song as "special" and said that he was willing to record a song that "strikes a nerve".<ref name="nerve">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/313209431/ | title=Billy Yates would like his songs to hit a nerve | work=The Indianapolis News | date=August 6, 1997 | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref> "Flowers" also received a [[music video]], which was nominated by ''Billboard'' at their 1997 Music Video Awards in the category of Best New Country Artist.<ref name="dylan"/> Writing for [[Country Standard Time]], Joel Bernstein praised Yates' voice and Fundis' production, but thought that the album's ballads were better written than the up-tempo songs.<ref name="cst debut">{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=195 | title=''Billy Yates'' review | publisher=Country Standard Time | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref> Bob Cannon of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' rated the album "C+", describing the song "Flowers" as "maudlin" and overall finding Yates' style imitative of [[Merle Haggard]].<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://ew.com/article/1997/07/11/billy-yates/ | title=''Billy Yates'' review | magazine=Entertainment Weekly | date=July 11, 1997 | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref>

Yates would chart only one more single for Almo Sounds, "When the Walls Come Tumblin' Down", before the label closed its Nashville division later in 1997.<ref name="whitburn"/><ref name="allmusic"/> Despite this, Jones covered another one of Yates's songs, "[[Choices (Billy Yates song)|Choices]]", on his 1999 album ''[[Cold Hard Truth (album)|Cold Hard Truth]]''. According to Yates, he had written the song in 1994 with the intent of having [[Alan Jackson]] record it; when Jackson did not record it, Yates recommended it to Jones, who turned it down twice before deciding to record it. The song was a top-30 country hit for Jones and won him the [[Grammy Award for Best Male Country Vocal Performance]] in 1999.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://americansongwriter.com/george-jones-choices/ | title=George Jones, "Choices" | date=January 2017 | publisher=American Songwriter | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref>

===2000–present: Columbia Records and independent===
In 2000, Yates signed with [[Columbia Records]] Nashville and charted one single, "What Do You Want from Me Now".<ref name="whitburn"/> It was his only released for the label before he left it in October 2001.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/hd2/IDX-Business/Music/Billboard-Index/IDX/2001/2001-10-27-Billboard-Page-0035.pdf | title=Nashville Scene | magazine=Billboard | pages=37 | date=October 27, 2001}}</ref> Yates told Country Standard Time in 2003 that he chose to leave Columbia because he felt that label executives considered his style too [[neotraditional country]] in nature to be successful.<ref name="cst page 2"/> Todd Sterling of AllMusic stated that Yates chose to leave Columbia due to a desire to record a more traditional sounding album, and that label executives agreed to release him from his contract after realizing that he did not wish to sign with a rival label.<ref name="allmusic"/>

After exiting Columbia, Yates founded his own label called M.O.D., an abbreviation for "my own damn records".<ref name="oldies">{{cite web | url=https://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Billy-Yates.html | title=Billy Yates biography | publisher=Oldies.com | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref> His first release on his own label was ''If I Could Go Back'' in 2001.<ref name="allmusic"/> The album's lead single was "Too Country and Proud of It".<ref name="oldies"/> Bobby Peacock of Roughstock reviewed the album favorably, with a focus on Yates' singing voice and lyrics in particular.<ref name="go back">{{cite web | url=http://roughstock.com/news/2010/11/18892-billy-yates-if-i-could-go-back | title=''If I Could Go Back'' review | publisher=Roughstock | date=November 24, 2010 |first=Bobby |last=Peacock | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref> His next independent album was 2003's ''Country''. According to an interview with Country Standard Time, the idea for the album's title track came to Yates in a dream. Another song on the album was "Smokin' Grass", which Yates co-wrote with [[Shannon Lawson]].<ref name="cst page 1"/> Lawson would later record the song himself and chart his version on Hot Country Songs in 2004.<ref>Whitburn, p. 203</ref> Two more independent albums, ''Anywhere but Nashville'' and ''Harmony Man'', followed in 2004 and 2005 respectively.<ref name="allmusic"/> Peacock reviewed ''Anwyhere but Nashville'' favorably for Roughstock, stating that "By releasing his music entirely on his own, Yates found ways to improve on the fine neotraditionalist sound he'd already built up on his underrated debut."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://roughstock.com/news/2010/11/18912-billy-yates-anywhere-but-nashville | title=''Anywhere but Nashville'' | publisher=Roughstock | date=November 21, 2010 | accessdate=August 4, 2021 | first=Bobby| last=Peacock}}</ref> Brian Wahlert of Country Standard Time reviewed the same project positively, stating that it contained "traditional country songs that display keen insight into everyday trials and joys, with a healthy dose of fun mixed in."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=194 | title=''Anywhere but Nashville'' review | publisher=Country Standard Time | accessdate=August 4, 2021}}</ref> In 2006, [[Chris Young (singer)|Chris Young]] covered "Flowers" on his [[Chris Young (album)|self-titled debut album]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Jurek|first=Thom|title=''Chris Young'' review|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r856320|pure_url=yes}}}}</ref>  Also in 2006, Yates founded the songwriting and publishing company Smokin' Grapes.<ref name="allmusic"/> One of the writers employed by his publishing company is Wil Nance, whose credits include the [[George Strait]] album cut "If Heartaches Were Horses". Yates himself would have other songwriting credits through Smokin' Grapes, including album cuts by [[Joe Nichols]] and [[Sara Evans]].<ref name="hats"/>

Yates' next album was 2008's ''That's Why I Run''. Todd Sterling of AllMusic wrote of this album that "Yates may be considered by some to be too country, but to his faithful fans, he's perfect just the way he is."<ref name="why i run">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/thats-why-i-run-mw0001709340 | title=''That's Why I Run'' | publisher=AllMusic | accessdate=July 16, 2021}}</ref> Two more discs came in 2009. First was a compilation called ''Favorites'', which included tracks from his previous albums, as well as a re-recording of "Choices" as a duet with Jones.<ref name="cmni"/> The other was ''Bill's Barber Shop'', the title track of which references the barber shop that Yates used to run. Also included on the album was a duet with Nicole Broussard on "I'll Do It for You". Ben Foster of Roughstock thought that the album had too many novelty songs, but otherwise praised Yates' lyricism and singing voice.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://roughstock.com/news/2010/12/18838-billy-yates-bills-barber-shop | title=''Bill's Barber Shop'' review | publisher=Roughstock | date=December 9, 2010 | accessdate=August 4, 2021 | first=Ben| last=Foster}}</ref> Yates toured several countries in Europe, including [[Switzerland]] and [[Lithuania]], to support this album. According to Yates, his music gained popularity on that continent thanks to fans discovering and downloading it via the Internet.<ref name="hats">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/304146213/ | title=Billy Yates wears many country music hats | work=The Tennessean | date=February 17, 2008 | accessdate=August 4, 2021 | pages=7}}</ref> He continued to tour Europe in 2011 in support of his next album, ''Just Be You''. Unlike his previous albums, Yates wrote every song by himself. "On My Way (The Norway Song)" was the album's lead single.<ref name="cmni">{{cite web | url=https://countrymusicnewsinternational.com/interview-with-billy-yates/ | title=Interview with Billy Yates | date=14 September 2011 | publisher=Country Music News International | accessdate=August 4, 2021}}</ref> His last independent album was 2015's ''These Old Walls'', which like its predecessors was supported through extensive touring in Europe.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://roughstock.com/news/2014/12/31378-billy-yates-announces-new-album-old-walls/ | title=Billy Yates announces new album 'These Old Walls' | publisher=Roughstock | date=December 15, 2014 | accessdate=August 4, 2021 | first=Matt| last=Bjorke}}</ref>

==Musical styles==
In an interview with Country Music News International, Yates cited [[Keith Whitley]], [[Webb Pierce]], [[Lefty Frizzell]], and [[Buck Owens]] among his main musical influences. He also stated that he preferred to record on his own label instead of on a major label, because of the amount of control he is able to maintain over his own music in terms of songwriting and production.<ref name="cmni"/> With regards to his songwriting style, Yates cites [[Harlan Howard]] as an influence as well.<ref name="nerve"/> Brian Wahlert of Country Standard Time and Bobby Peacock of Roughstock both compared Yates' voice favorably to that of [[Gene Watson]].<ref name="cst debut"/><ref name="go back"/> Writing for AllMusic, Todd Sterling called Yates' singing and songwriting style "traditional", stating that his songs were "real people singing about real things".<ref name="why i run"/> He also noted the frequent use of [[fiddle]], [[acoustic guitar]], and [[steel guitar]] in Yates' production.<ref name="why i run"/>

==Personal life==
Billy Yates has been married to his wife, Nancy, since the release of "Flowers" in 1997.<ref name="cmni"/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.spokesman.com/stories/1997/jun/22/music-with-a-message-billy-yates-new-song-about-a/ | title=Music with a message: Billy Yates' new song about a recovering alcoholic's apology to his wife has people listening | publisher=Miami Herald | date=June 22, 1997 | accessdate=August 4, 2021 | first=Howard| last=Cohen}}</ref> They have one son named Grayson, who was ten years old when he provided guest vocals on ''Just Be You''.<ref name="cmni"/> In 2015, Yates had a section of [[U.S. Highway 160]] outside his hometown of Doniphan named after him. State senator [[Mike Cunningham (politician)|Mike Cunningham]] attended the naming ceremony, which also included musical performances by [[Jimmy Fortune]] and [[Buddy Jewell]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2598 | title=Senator Cunningham attends dedication of Billy Yates highway in Ripley County | work=The Douglas County Herald | date=June 11, 2015 | accessdate=August 4, 2021 | pages=A3}}</ref>
